meanings.definition: Relating to or explaining phenomena in terms of purpose or end goals.
meanings.sent1: The scientist proposed a teleological explanation for the behavior of the ants.
meanings.sent2: Many philosophers debate the teleological nature of the universe.
meanings.sent3: It was a teleological twist of fate that led to their unexpected meeting.
meanings.sent4: Her teleological approach to problem-solving always yielded innovative solutions.
meanings.sent5: The teleological view of history suggests that events are guided by a higher purpose.

meanings.definition: Characterized by or relating to the belief in purpose or design in nature.
meanings.sent1: The ancient civilization had a teleological view of the world, seeing everything as part of a grand plan.
meanings.sent2: Many religious texts contain teleological explanations for the creation of the world.
meanings.sent3: It was a teleological miracle that the flowers bloomed just in time for the wedding.
meanings.sent4: The teleological patterns in nature hint at a divine creator.
meanings.sent5: The teleological argument posits that the complexity of life points to an intelligent designer.

meanings.definition: Involving or relating to the study of goals or purposes in natural phenomena.
meanings.sent1: The teleological approach to ecology focuses on understanding the purpose of ecosystems.
meanings.sent2: Scientists use teleological reasoning to explore the intentions behind animal behavior.
meanings.sent3: It was a teleological breakthrough that revolutionized the field of botany.
meanings.sent4: The teleological perspective sheds light on the interconnectedness of species in an ecosystem.
meanings.sent5: Studying the teleological aspects of evolution reveals the underlying purpose in adaptation.
